title: WISH: spack install defaulting to --jobs=$SPACK_PARALLEL_JOBS
body:
The number of parallel jobs when installing can be controlled as:
```sh
spack install --jobs <njobs> foo
```
If `--jobs` is not specified, the [default is to make use of all cores on the machine](https://github.com/LLNL/spack/blob/v0.10.0/lib/spack/spack/build_environment.py#L355) using `multiprocessing.cpu_count()`.

I'd like to propose that the default could be controlled via an environment variable, e.g. `SPACK_PARALLEL_JOBS` such that if it is set, it's value will be used instead of `multiprocessing.cpu_count()`.

The advantage of `SPACK_PARALLEL_JOBS` is that one don't have to specify `--jobs` explicitly.  If a shared system has a build machine with multiple users, sysadm can set the default number of parallel jobs to say, `SPACK_PARALLEL_JOBS=4`.  If building via a scheduler such as TORQUE / PBS, one set it as `export SPACK_PARALLEL_JOBS=$PBS_NUM_PPN`.


PS. Parallel jobs can be [disabled using `SPACK_NO_PARALLEL_MAKE=true`](https://github.com/LLNL/spack/blob/v0.10.0/lib/spack/spack/build_environment.py#L112-L113).  This could be replaced with `SPACK_PARALLEL_JOBS=1`.
